p: The ecological and evolutionary consequences of climate change are of considerable concern for the conservation of species, populations and communities. In recent times, rapidly rising mean temperatures have altered the distributions of populations and communities, typically causing shifts to higher latitudes and altitudes [ 1] and changing flowering times, migration times and developmental schedules [ 2– 4]. Many of these changes are detrimental [ 5]. For example, plant–pollinator and predator–prey interactions have been disrupted by alterations in species' phenologies [ 6– 9]. However, analysis of the impacts of contemporary climate change is only now starting to move from documentation to explanation of its effects [ 10, 11].
